Sarah Stewart likes to think about what happens when planets collide she uses to actual cannons to simulate those massive impact here's one firing in her lab at UC Davis
Her work earned her a spot in this year's class of MacArthur fellows many of us call it the genius grant for years experts of thought the earth's moon formed after a large coalition knocked off a bunch of rock Stewart told me her research suggests a different story
During planet formation when two bodies collide there's so much energy released that most of these bodies are vaporized that means that a rocky planet like earth is mostly rock vapor
What does rock vapor and and what does it have to do with our moon
Rock paper is taking the rocks that we stand on end heating it up to the point where it becomes a gas
And when that occurs the earth becomes much larger because vapor is much less dense ... and it extends out into this enormous object hundreds of times larger than the earth today and we proposed that our moon grows within the rock vapor of the earth after a giant impact
So the moon actually came from the earth
The moon grows within the rock paper of the earth and that gives the moon the same chemistry and see her
How much of a revelation was that I mean how different was that from what scientists used to think about where the moon came from
It was hard to imagine that things could be so different and it was a mental roadblock to realize that giant impacts transformed a planet into an entirely new type of object and that could explain one of the biggest mysteries in the solar system
